Natural Heritage Trust 1998 Mr ADAMS (Lyons) (5.49 p.m.)-Let me first say that it is disgraceful that the adjournment debate has been taken up with government business. It is a sad state. The Liberal Party gives away the position of Speaker from its party room and then will not even stand up and let the backbench have the time to have a say in this parliament. You have come a long way down. There might be a few of you over that side, but you do not have much backbone in the party room. Yesterday the member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) commented on the amount from the Natural Heritage Trust that was being spent in Lyons. If you take that sum in isolation from the rest of the grants, it might look reasonably fair. However, it is small compensation for the amount of money that has been ripped out of Lyons. It is very inadequate compensation. It is a sop to a few Liberal mates down there to stop them whingeing at first the government. That is exactly why they have put the money there. Funds and jobs for Lyons have been decimated. There have been closures all over the place. In the north of the state, we have had the removal of the Family Court; we have had the closure of the tax office; and the latest news is that the Defence Force recruitments office is to be disbanded and shipped over to Victoria. It is a despicable act by the government which was done by stealth. The recruitment personnel have played an enormous role in going around to the schools all over the state, and on Flinders and King islands, to talk to them and explain how kids can gear up their studies for entry into the forces and what assistance they can get to do that. These children rarely go into the city. the opportunity for a rewarding career in the defence forces is going to be lost to them. Now there will be a visit once a year from some stranger out of Victoria who does not know the families, will not be able to keep an eye on the kids and is not interested to help them apply when the opportunity comes. All these things have an enormous impact on Lyons and on the families that live within its boundaries. People are not taken in by these measly amounts which are being offered to a few people-like to the state government for various projects, to the local councils to do some of the work that really should be done by the state government anyway and for some fencing for local farmers to fence in natural bush for a growth area. There are some good projects among those that were put forward. Some were funded but a lot were not funded. Only last weekend I visited a group at Carrick, a small historical town at the end of my electorate. They had applied for money on numerous occasions and were disappointed that they had never been funded. Undeterred, that group has done a terrific job. The local people, along with the local Lions Club and other community organisations, have done a terrific job cleaning out a creek and a river. They have put back the local swimming hole and have a place to put a boat on the river. They have done that without funding. With a little bit of funding, they could have done a hell of a lot more. I am grateful for what has been offered but I would like to see more and I want to see some job development programs. I want to see some assistance to small towns to keep them viable. I want to see opportunities for kids. I want to see a stop to this closing of banks, hospitals and post offices. We want to retain our police presence in these areas. We want to keep the country and make it live again. Just throwing this token money around will not achieve those basic things. We have to have jobs going back into the country. We need some special projects and some training to create those jobs. We can make them relevant and provide an opportunity for the community. That is what we need. If these funds mean that the country areas will So be taken seriously by the government and stop the wholesale slaughter of facilities out of the electorate of Lyons and the state of Tasmania, I welcome the money, but it is not enough. We have to get on to economic development and look at supporting small towns with small communities by keeping services in those areas. (Time expired) Small Business Ms. GAMBARO (Petrie) (5.54 p.m.)Congratulations, Me Speaker, on your - l-va tion. I also want to congratulate the Mmlster for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) for two very significant events that occurred during the past week. They both deal with the small business sector, a sector that I have had very close involvement with in recent months, particularly in the new areas of my electorate of Petrie which I picked up from the electorates of Dickson and Brisbane in the recent Queensland redistribution. Small business people along Stafford Road, Old Northern Road and MCDowall were very interested in the federal government's reforms. In fact, I was very surprised that many businesses which were previously in the electorate of the member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) knew very little about the small business sector and what this government was doing. Every small business needs to be aware of this government's initiative, with its 'new deal, fair deal' package for small business.The benefits are absolutely immense and every small business deserves to know about and to be informed of these measures. The first announcement that I would like to deal with was the announcement that the Australian banking industry has acknowledged the small business sector by widening the coverage of the ombudsman scheme. This was an initiative which was a direct result of the fair trading inquiry undertaken by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, of which I was an active participant and the only Queensland government member on that committee. This decision by the banking industry comes after this government, through the great efforts of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, took that initiative and worked with the banking industry to achieve reforms for the small business sector. I also wish to acknowledge a report that came out in February by the Micro Consultative Task Force. They were very appreciative of the work that had been done in the fair trading report and particularly in the ombudsman scheme. Previously the Australian Banking Industry Ombudsman did not extend to small business. It has been the government's belief that the scheme should apply to all small businesses. The fact that the banking industry will also develop a charter for small business is a very positive step and one that needs to be commended. I would also like to take this opportunity congratulate those appointed to - he Franchising Council. I know that the chairman, the Hon. Michael Mackellar, will undertake his task with great dignity and respect. The representatives cover a wide range of industries from a cross-section of very well-known companies-companies such as Pizza Haven, Oz Design and MCDonald's. I would also like to take this opportunity to congratulate one of Australia's leading franchising attorneys and a representative from Queensland, Mr Joseph Panettiere, on his appointment. The Franchising Council has been designated with a workload that will cover a number of areas, including: undertaking a review of the franchising code of practice; obtaining agreement on the franchising code; monitoring the operation of the code; and developing a strategic plan for the franchising policy council covering issues of the relationship with the ACCC, the code of review and industry liaison. Furthermore, areas in the code which are to be reviewed include things such as: financial projections; prohibiting conduct that has occurred in the past such as churning, stock dumping and rent loading; the use of dispute resolution processes; and setting absolute minimum standards for disclosure documents for franchisors and franchisees. The franchising industry in Australia is following trends around the world. It is just growing from strength to strength. The practicalities therefore are to ensure that this particular growth is not stifled by things such as risk and instability. The government needs to be congratulated on its efforts in this much needed area of reform. In relation to retail tenancy reform, franchising reform, unfair conduct and trade practices and small business education, this government is not just looking at the problems which exist but is acting on them and delivering great and positive results. I wish to wholeheartedly endorse the work that has been done on fair trading and the work that is continuing on a day by day basis. I know that the Franchising Policy Council will undertake that reform and will continue with the great work that has already been an to initiative for the benefit not only of the franchising industry but for the whole of the small business community in Australia. I wish to particularly commend the work that they will be doing, and also to continue working with the minister on these much needed reforms. Schools Funding

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Very briefly, I wish to refute an article which appeared in the Sun Weekly on the Central Coast today, indicating that the federal government had cut back funding to government schools and that the cutbacks had caused the school children at Umina High to allocate money that they had raised selling sweets tofix up the toilets at Umina High. The federal government has actually increased funding to government schools in New South Wales by $41 million. It is absolute rubbish to say that the school children had to go and sell sweets to raise money to fix the toilets. at Umina High. That is actually a state government responsibility. I call on the state member, Ms Marie Andrews, the member for Peats, to get out there and do something about that and to make sure that the school children at Umina High have decent facilities and decent infrastructure at their school.

Main Committee adjourned at 1.00 p.m. NA The following answers to questions were circulated: (Question No. 2127) Mr Mossfield asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 25 August 1997: (1) Is he able to say why banks insist on a four to five day clearance period for cheques banked by a customer into his or her account, during which period the customer is unable to access the funds. (2) Is he able to say whether banks are able to provide a same day clearance for a cheque from another bank which is used to pay a credit card account; if so, (a) why and (b) why are customers denied the same service. (3) Is he also able to say whether interest is credited on monies banked but which are inaccessible to customers, if not, why not. Mr Costello:-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The time it takes to clear a cheque is a function of the time needed to transport, process and check the authenticity of the cheque, plus an allowance for the time it takes for any advice of dishonour to get back to the institution where the cheque was deposited. Where the bank is the recipient of the cheque, as is the case when a credit card account is paid, it must also take into account these factors. The current five-day clearance cycle for cheques is an industry standard although banks will allow some customers to draw against particular cheque deposits within the five-day period. In such situations, the bank in question is making a commercial judgement that the cheque will be paid, or that in the event of dishonour it can recover the funds it has allowed its customer to withdraw. I am conscious of community concern that the five-day cycle does not reflect developments in processing and communication technology in the banking industry. The Reserve Bank has been pressing the Australian Payments Clearing Association (whose membership includes banks, building societies and credit unions) to speed up its project to require electronic presentment of cheques and electronic communication of dishonour, with the objective of reducing cheque clearing times. I understand that this could reduce the current fiveday clearance cycle to three or four days without increasing the risk that dishonour advice is received NA Banking after cheque proceeds have been allowed to be withdrawn. (2) Where a cheque is used to pay a credit card account, the (outstanding) balance of the account is immediately reduced, but it is at the discretion of the bank whether or not the credit lirnit is restored until the cheque has been cleared. This is the same treatment as cheques deposited to a customer's account whereby the account is credited and interest accrued, although the proceeds may generally not be withdrawn until the cheque has been cleared (see question 3 below). (3) Cheques deposited to an account accrue interest in the normal fashion from the day on which the cheque is deposited even though the funds have not been cleared and may generally not be withdrawn. Superannuation: Non-Residents (Question No. 2131) Mr Mossfield asked the Minister representing the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 25 August 1997: Will legislation be amended to allow non-residents who leave Australia to return to their homeland to be paid, at the time of their departure, superannuation entitlements they may have built up during their time in Australia, and not be required to remember claim entitlements when they reach 65 years of age. Mr Costello-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: No. From 1 July 1998, a person who departs Australia permanently will no longer have automatic access to their preserved superannuation benefits. Rather, he or she will only be able to access preserved superannuation benefits on retirement at or after the preservation age (currently 55) or under other conditions of release, subject to the governing rules of the superannuation fund. Charitable Organisations: Tax Deductions (Question No. 2145) Mr MCClelland asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 August 1997: Will the Government increase the threshold before which a charitable organisation can be tax deductible; if so, what will be the threshold amount before a charitable donation is tax deductible. Mr Costello-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: The provisions for income tax deductibility of gifts are set out in Division 30 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997. For a gift to be deductible, it must have a value of $2 or more. The Government has made no announcement regarding changes to this provision. Commercial Airlines: Screening of (Question No. 2179) Mr Tanner asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 1 September 1997: (1) Who has formal responsibility for the screening of passengers boarding commercial aircraft at Australian airports. (2) Does his Department have a role in monitoring the performance of screening operations; if so, in what way. (3) Is training and certification required for a person to undertake passenger screening at Australian airports; if so, what. Mr Vaile-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Currently, individual aircraft operators are responsible for arranging the screening of passengers boarding large commercial aircraft within Australia. However, the Government proposes that responsibility for passenger screening and sterile area access control at Australia's major airports should rest with the operator of the terminal from which passengers board an aircraft. A Bill, to give effect to this proposal, is currently before the Parliament. (2) Yes. The Department formally audits and informally monitors airlines' compliance against their security programs. The Department also sets testing standards for screening equipment and conducts regular checks that the equipment is operating up to standard. The Department also conducts unannounced covert tests of the effectiveness of the screening function. (3) The Department has set a standard for the content of screener training programs and is Office currently discussing with industry the introduction' of more extensive requirements for screener training. Wholesale Sales Tax (Question No. 2191) Mr Eoin Cameron asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 September, 1997. (1) Does wholesale sales tax apply to new cars: if so, at what rates. (2) What total sum has been collected from wholesale sales tax on new cars since 1989-90. (3) At what rate d-d the wholesale sales tax originally apply to new cars. (4) Has the rate changed since it was first Passengers introduced; if so, (a) when and (b) what are the details. (5) What sum would be forgone if the wholesale sales tax on new cars did not apply in (a) 1998-99. (b) 1999-2000 and (c) 2000-01. Mr Costello-The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (1) Yes. New cars with a wholesale value up to and including $36,995 are presently taxed at 22%. New cars with a wholesale value above $36,995 are taxed at 45%. (2) No figures are available specifically for wholesale sales tax on new cars, however, total sales tax collected on goods comprising motor cars, commercial vehicles, motor bodies, semi-trailers etc since 1989-90 is approximately $13 billion. (3) Upon introduction of the wholesale sales tax regime in 1930 the rate of 2.5% applied to all goods, including new cars. (4) Motor vehicles have been subject to sales tax since 1930. The rate of tax applicable to motor vehicles has changed in line with the rates applicable to other goods in the past 67 years. Given the long time span and the number of changes that have occurred the exact details of all the rate changes that have occurred since 1930 are not readily available. (5) Agencies in my portfolio do not often compile forecasts of sales tax revenue to be collected or foregone from individual products. Historical experience is that when such forecasts are compiled and published, it is usually in the context of a budget measure to newly impose sales tax on a product. No such tax measures will apply during this Parliament, as the Government is committed not to introduce new taxes. However, it may be of assistance to the honourable member to note that the latest edition of the Australian Taxation publication 'Taxation Statistics' records that $2547 million in sales tax was collected in 1995-96 from businesses whose major taxable sales were in the field of motor cars and commercial vehicles. Treasury: Staff (Question No. 2205) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 September 1997: (1) How many persons were employed in the (a) Department of the Treasury, (b) Reserve Bank of Australia, (c) Australian Consumer and Competition Commission, (d) Australian Securities Commission, (e) Australian Bureau of Statistics, (0 Australian Competition Tribunal, (g) Australian Loan Council, (h) Australian Statistics Advisory Council, (i) Companies and Securities Advisory Committee, (j) Economic Planning Advisory Commission, (k) Industry Commission, (1) Insurance and Superannuation Commission, (m) National Competition Council, (n) Superannuation Complaints Tribunal, (0) Foreign Investment Review Board and (p) Ministerial Council for Corporations on (i) 1 March 1996 and (ii) 1 September 1997. (2) What are the current classification employees of the authorities referred to in part (1). Mr Costello---The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) and (2) The 1995-96 and 1996-97 Annual Reports of the organisations apart from those mentioned below contain information on persons employed and their classification levels. In relation to the remaining organisations: (g) Australian Loan Council The Australian Loan Council is comprised of the Treasurer of the Commonwealth (who chairs the Council) and the Premiers, Chief Ministers or Treasurers of States and Territories. Secretariat support services are provided by the Fiscal Policy Division of the Department of the Treasury. (p) Ministerial Council for Corporations The Ministerial Council for Corporations was established by the Heads of Agreement of June 1990 between the Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory Ministers on future corporate regulation in Australia. The principal function of the Ministerial Council is the consideration of legislative proposals relating to the national companies and securities scheme. The Ministerial Council consists of one member representing each party to the Heads of Agreement/Corporations Agreement who is the Minister responsible for administering a national scheme law of that party. The parties are the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory. The Ministerial Council itself employs no staff. Secretariat services for the Ministerial Council are provided by the Business Law Division of the Treasury. Charitable and Religious Organisations: Tax Exemptions (Question No. 2222) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1997: (1) Have Australian based religious, charitable and other organisations made representations to his office with respect to proposed measures to address tax avoidance through the use of tax exempt entities which distribute their proceeds off-shore; if so, how many. (2) How many existing religious, charitable and other organisations will pass the exemption test of physical presence and Australian based expenditure proposed in recent legislation. (3) What will be the impact on federal revenue in 1997-98 if the legislation is passed unamended. (4) Will he review the operation of the legislalevels for tion in 1998. Mr Costello---The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (1) In the 1996-97 Budget, the Government announced that it intended to proceed with an announcement by the previous Government and introduce legislation to counter tax avoidance through the use of tax-exempt bodies distributing funds offshore. It also undertook to release an exposure draft of the legislation with a view to obtaining submissions from interested parties. The exposure draft was released on 20 February 1997 and some 78 formal submissions were received. In addition many telephone calls were received and a and number of meetings held. Many of the submissions expressed support for the Government's measures to counter tax avoidance, but some expressed concern about some possible unintended effects on bona fide bodies. The Government has carefully considered all of the representations received and where the integrity of the measures could still be maintained, incorporated many of the suggestions made in the Bill introduced into the Parliament and in the amendment moved by the Government in the Parliament. (2) It is expected that the vast majority of tax exempt organisations that have a physical presence in Australia will be unaffected by the measures. Those charitable or religious institution that have a physical presence in Australia but incur their expenditure and pursue their objects principally outside Australia will lose the general tax exemption previously available. However, in these circumstances, it will still be possible for the institutions to retain their tax exempt status if the Parliament prescribes the particular institution in the Income Tax Regulations. (3) The estimated impact of these measures is a gain to the revenue of $30 million per annum from 1997-98. (4) Extensive public consultation has already taken place on the legislation and the Government made amendments to the draft bill to remove unintended consequences. However the ATO will continue to monitor the operation of the legislation to ensure it continues to operate in the manner intended. Wage Increases (Question No. 2224) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Treasurer upon notice, on 23 September 1997: (1) Does data released on enterprise agreement based wage increases over the past 12 months tally with his Department's forecasts on wage growth. (2) Is the level of wage increase excessive; if so, what measures will be taken to slow wage growth. Mr Costello-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Data on enterprise agreement based wage increases released by the Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business shows an average annual wage increase of 4.6 per cent per employee for Federal wage agreements formalised in the September quarter 1997. This compares with an average annual wage increase of 4.8 per cent per employee for agreements formalised in the June quarter 1997, 4.6 per cent for March quarter 1997 agreements and 4.4 per cent for December quarter 1996 agreements. Federal enterprise agreements currently account for around 15 per cent of the workforce. The remainder of the workforce receive wage increases through State enterprise agreements, safety net increases to award rates, unregistered collective agreements and individual employment agreements or unilateral management decisions. Enterprise agreement based wage increases are not inconsistent with the Government's aggregate wage forecast contained in the 1997-98 Budget. (2) As noted above, the rate of enterprise agreement based wage increases is not inconsistent with the Government's aggregate wage forecast. Enterprise bargaining gives employers and employees primary responsibility for wage setting arrangements. Such wage outcomes will reflect more accurately the interests of those directly involved and offers the potential for higher wage increases supported by improvements in productivity. Productivity driven pay rises can enable workers to enjoy above average pay increases without resulting in rising inflation. Commonwealth Government Centre, Hobart (Question No. 2297) Mr Kerr asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 29 September 1997: (1) Is the Commonwealth Government Centre in Hobart tenanted: if not why not. (2) Have several Commonwealth Departments and agencies vacated the centre; if so, why. (3) Is the centre half empty; if so, what action is proposed for the property. Mr Fahey-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Yes. (2) No. One agency vacated in May 1997 after expiry of its short term lease. (3) No. Trusts (Question No. 2366) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 October 1997: Is the Government preparing a discussion paper on trusts; if so (a) when will it be released, (b) who is compiling it and (c) will the Government invite comments from the Australian community on the discussion paper prior to considering legislative changes to the laws concerning trusts. Mr Costello-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: In the 1997-98 Budget, presented on 13 May 1997, the Government announced its intention to review the taxation of trusts, with a Treasury/Australian Taxation Office discussion paper to be prepared in the lead up to the review to outline relevant tax issues and broad policy options. On 23 February 1998, I announced that the review of trusts will now proceed as part of the Government's tax reform program, in place of the officials' paper previously announced. Interested parties that would have participated in the consultation process on the discussion paper are invited to forward submissions to the Chair of the Tax Consultative Task Force, Senator the Hon Brian Gibson, by 31 March 1998. (Submissions on other matters closed on 27 February 1998). As I announced in the 1997-98 Budget, the Government reserves the right to take earlier legislative action to prevent tax minimisation or avoidance by the use of trusts or limited partnerships. Revenue Forecasts (Question No. 2367) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 October 1997: Has his attention been drawn to a report by Access Economics which forecasts that revenue in 1998-99 could be up to $4 billion more than currently anticipated; if so (a) does he support the forecast and (b) what steps has he or his Department taken to revise revenue estimates for 1997-98, 1998-99 and 1999-2000. Mr Costello-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: I am aware of the report by Access Economics. (a) and (b) The Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook report released in December 1997 contains the Government's assessments of the economic outlook and associated implications for revenue and outlays. Telstra Privatisation: Government (Question No. 2370) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 October 1997: (1) Will the part-privatisation of Telstra impact upon Federal Government revenue in 1998; if so, to what extent. (2) Would the sale of the remaining two thirds of Telstra impact upon Federal Government revenue; if so, to what extent. (3) Will the Government use the revenue generated by the Telstra part-privatisation to fund tax cuts in 1998, 1999,2000 or 2001; if so, how will the tax cuts be sustained once the revenue from the Telstra sale has been exhausted. Mr Costello-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The amount of the dividend foregone in 1998 will depend on the profit performance of Telstra in 1997-98. (2) The Government has stated that it will not sell any further Commonwealth equity in Telstra without first obtaining a mandate from the Australian public. (3) I do not intend to respond to conjecture about tax. The Government has announced that it will make its tax reform proposals clear to the Australian public before the next election. Australian Container Ports (Question No. 2399) Mr MCClelland asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 22 October 1997: (1) Which are the major Australian container ports. (2) For each port referred to in (I), has there been (a) a reduction in the stevedoring workforce, (b) an increase in the number of containers handled per person per shift, (c) a reduction in container terminal charges, (d) a reduction in shift tum around times and (e) an increase in crane rates in the period from 1990 until the present; if so, what are the details. Mr Reith-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The major Australian container ports are Melbourne, Sydney, Brisbane, Fremantle, Burnie and Adelaide. (2) (a) The stevedoring workforce is employed on a company basis and is a matter for each individual company. There is no central registry Revenue from which total numbers can be drawn on a portby-port basis. However, the nation-wide stevedoring workforce has fallen from 8,872 in late 1989 to around 4,000 today. There are many issues relating to inefficient work practices that impact on the cost of using Australia's waterfront and therefore on the competitiveness of Australian exporters. Because of the long term monopoly labour supply controlled by the Maritime Union of Australia, it is not clear that manning requirements in container stevedoring operations are determined on the basis of workload and working arrangements optimised by the needs of the enterprise. The aim of the Government's industrial relations framework and waterfront reform objectives is to give stevedoring operators the opportunity to work on a more commercial footing. This extends to giving operators greater control over manning levels and the size of their workforce irrespective of whether employees are or are not members of the MUA. (b) This information is not available on a consistent and uniform basis. (c) Container terminal charges are a commercial matter for each stevedoring company in each port. Reports previously published by the former Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA) provided an average national figure for revenue per twenty-foot equivalent unit (TEU) across all major container ports. These figures ranged from $254 per TEU in 1990 to $193 per TEU in 1993 and a preliminary estimate of $203 per TEU in 1996. The Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics' (BTCE) in its latest (September 1997) Waterline publication uses a national average of $188 per TED, based on PSA figures and industry sources, while noting that charges may vary between ports and that detailed data for individual ports is not publicly available. Despite the decrease in the national average revenue per TED figure indicated here, evidence suggests stevedoring costs at Australian ports remain higher than at comparable overseas ports. The cost of using port facilities has a serious impact on trade competitiveness as costs must be fully included in the price of exported products. Banking (Question No. 2480) Mr MCClelland asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 November 1997: (1) Is he able to say how current cheque clearance rates of Australian banks compare with world best practice. (2) If cheque clearance rates are below world best practice, what measures will the Government implement to ensure that Australian banks meet world best practice. Mr Costello--The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The Australian standard cheque clearing cycle is currently five days. Compared to similar countries, this is one of the longest times for funds from a cheque deposit to become available. Nevertheless, care must be taken in making such comparisons. In Australia, the availability of funds is the same for all cheques, irrespective of where in Australia they are presented, while in many countries non-local cheques can take a very long time to clear. Australian banks pay interest from the day a cheque is presented (even though the funds may not be withdrawn), while in some other countries interest is paid only once cleared funds become available. However, the Final Report of the Financial System Inquiry (the Wallis Report) noted that industry arrangements for processing and clearing have constrained the efficiency of cheque clearing, as they fail to capture the scale economies available through more centralised processing. Centralised processing provides a further means of reducing cheque processing costs and cheque clearing times. However, banks have been reluctant to date to adopt centralised processing on a widespread scale, despite the availability of third party processing capacity. (2) The Reserve Bank has been pressing the Australian Payments Clearing Association (APCA), whose membership includes banks, building societies and credit unions, to reduce cheque clearing times by speeding up its project to replace physical transfers of cheques by electronic systems. APCA has developed new standards and procedures for the electronic presentment and dishonour of cheques with a view to shortening the time it takes to clear a cheque. APCA's CEO has said that this will allow financial institutions to decide three days after deposit whether to provide clear funds. APCA recently announced a timetable for the progressive conversion of cheque exchanges to the new procedures by the end of April 1999. The Government and the Reserve Bank will be watching closely to see that financial institutions take advantage of these systems developments to reduce cheque clearing times and improve customer service in this respect. Expo 2000 World Trade Fair (Question No. 2509) Mrs Crosio asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 18 November 1997: (1) Did he decide that Australia would not participate in the Expo 2000 World Trade Fair in Hanover, Germany; if so, (a) when, (b) why, (c) did he or any other representative of his Government inform the German government of the decision when it was made, (d) which representative of the German government was informed and (e) what was the official response from the German government. (2) During his official state visit to Australia in May 1997, did the German Chancellor, Dr Helmut Kohl, discuss Australia's participation in Expo 2000 with him; if so, (a) what was the nature of the discussion and (b) did he give the Chancellor any undertakings regarding Australia's participation in the event; if so, what undertakings. (3) Has he, or his representative, ever given an assurance to Dr Kohl or a representative of the German government that Australia would participate in Expo 2000. (4) During his official state visit to Australia in November 1997, did the Prime Minister of The Netherlands, Mr Wim Kok, state that Australia risked missing the economic boat in the run up to the European Monetary Union in 1999 if it did not increase its economic contacts with Europe; if so, is the decision not to participate in Expo 2000 (a) counter to Mr Kok's advice and (b) the loss of a crucial opportunity to strengthen Australia's economic ties with countries in the region; if not, why not. (5) Is it a fact that the only way Australia will participate in Expo 2000 is if the costs associated with such participation are met by State Governments or by some other avenue. (6) Is the Government reviewing its stance on contributing funding to guarantee Australia's participation in Expo 2000; if so, (a) whit sum is the Government willing to contribute and (b) will he explain why it is reviewing its stance; if not, why not. (7) Is he able to say whether State governments will present to the Government a plan for funding the Australian pavilion at Expo 2000; if so, (a) has he been informed of (i) the content of the plan and (ii) when it will be presented and (b) which State governments have expressed an interest in funding Australia's participation. (8) Have confusion and controversy surrounding Australia's participation in Expo 2000 (a) been a major cause of embarrassment for Australia in Europe and (b) represented a low point in relations between Australia and Germany; if not, why not.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS ON NOTICE
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1)-(7) The Government decided not to fully fund Australian participation in Expo 2000 in the 1996-97 Budget context. In light of further consideration, including representations by the German Chancellor, Dr Helmut Kohl and Premiers and Chief Ministers, I announced on 1 December 1997 that the Commonwealth will accept a shared funding offer proposed by the Premier of Queensland, the Hon Rob Borbidge. Under the arrangement, the States and Territories will contribute $8.5 million towards the cost of an Australian pavilion, with a matching contribution from the Commonwealth. (2) Is it a fact that the Commonwealth will spend $87.5 million over the next three years on drug rehabilitation, education, prevention and crime fighting. (3) Will most of the sum referred to in part (2) be allocated to the areas of Australia with greatest need; if so, which areas are considered to be of greatest need. (4) If the areas in greatest need have not been identified, how will they be determined. (5) Will non-government agencies need to proceed through a tender system in order to obtain Commonwealth funding for their work under the campaign; if so, will he outline the system; if not, why not.

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: QUESTIONS ON NOTICE
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The child education component of "Tough on Drugs" recently announced by the Prime Minister will be administered by the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (DEETYA). DEETYA has advised that while the School Drug Education Strategy will cally based on the Swedish model there are similarities between the Swedish and Australian approaches to drugs policy. The Swedish drug policy can be described as a close interaction between preventive measures, control policy and treatment of drug abusers, with the aim of a drug-free society. This model is similar to the Australian Government's "Tough on Drugs" strategy which is designed to deliver an integrated approach to reducing the supply and demand of illicit drugs and minimise the harm they cause. (2) Yes. The Commonwealth is providing $87.5 million over three years as a first instalment towards the new National Illicit Drug Strategy "Tough on Drugs" which will form part of the next major phase of the National Drug Strategy. For further details I refer the honourable member to the Prime Minister's press release of 2 NovemDrugs ber 1997. (3) & (4) Yes; funding will be allocated as follows: interception of illicit drugs-$43.8 million . education-$14.0 million . rehabilitation and research-$29.8 million Additional funding for establishing and operating new facilities for treating illicit drug problems will target geographical target group gaps in the coverage of existing services. (5) An open tender process will be conducted for several parts of the package, including the community grants program and non-government treatment facilities, seeking submissions from key non-government organisations. State and territory health departments will .also be consulted on projects to address areas of highest need within their jurisdictions. The final selection of tenderers will be made in consultation with states and territory health departments to ensure that there is the consistency between their overall drug treatment . strategies and the initiatives funded under the National Illicit Drug Strategy. Volunteer Workers (Question No. 2561) Mr Andren asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 November 1997: Is it a fact that car allowances paid to volunteer workers for travelling to and from their place of voluntary work are treated as assessable income by the Australian Taxation Office but not as income by the Department of Social Security when assessing eligibility of volunteer workers for assistance; if so, (a) why and (b) what steps will the Government take to address the inconsistency. Mr Costell-The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: The treatment by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) of payments to volunteer workers is not inconsistent with the treatment of similar payments by the Department of Social Security (DSS). The ATO will not generally treat as assessable income, a payment to a volunteer worker that represents a fair reimbursement of car expenses for travelling to and from his or her place of voluntary work. For example, the ATO will accept as fair reimbursement, a payment calculated on a cents per kilometre basis at the rate published annually by the Commissioner of Taxation. Similarly, DSS would not assess as income a reimbursement to a volunteer worker by an agency for out-of-pocket expenses incurred, such as travel expenses. On the other hand, if a volunteer worker receives an allowance, with no regard to expenses actually incurred and with no requirement to repay unspent monies, the ATO will generally treat the payment as assessable income. Each case needs to be determined on its own facts. If a volunteer worker receives an allowance to cover out-of-pocket expenses, DSS would assess as income the excess over actual expenses incurred. Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: MOTOR TRANSPORT
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The Department of Health and Family Services administers a wide range of programs which provide assistance to the general community and which assist indigenous people as part of that general community. Some of these general community programs also provide services which are targeted to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. These programs include the Children's Services Program, the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program, the Emergency Relief Program, the Home and Community Care Program and' the Aged Care Program. My Department also administers the Aboriginal Health Services Program and the Aboriginal Substance Misuse Program which provide services specifically for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. All of these programs provide services to indigenous people living in the Commonwealth Electorate of Grey. . (2) (a, b, c) It is not possible to provide figures on the proportion of funding of general community programs which would support the needs of indigenous people because of the lack of reliable information on their utilisation of such programs. (3) The Department does not routinely provide data on the level of funding allocated by federal electorate. Pensioners Asset Test (Question No. 2570) Mr Allan Morris asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 27 November 1997: . (1) Is it a fact that while the pensioners' asset test taper of $78 per annum of pension withdrawn for each $1000 in assets above the threshold Grants effectively assumes a rate of return of 7.8 per cent per annum on the assets, the deemed rate of return for financial assets is between 3 and 5 per cent. (2) Does the situation described in part (1) result in (a) discrimination against pensioners owning assets other than financial investments and (b) encouragement of the transfer of investment from assets other than financial assets to financial assets; if so (i) why does the situation exist and (ii) will the Government make the assets test taper consistent with the deeming rate. Mr Ruddock-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (1) The assets test does withdraw pension at a rate of $78 per annum for each $1000 in assets above the threshold. The withdrawal rate under the assets test was not designed to reflect investment returns but rather to reflect the Government's intention that people with significant assets utilise those resources before calling on the community for income support through the Social Security system. The withdrawal rate applies to all assessable assets, financial and non-financial. These are the rules which applied under the previous Government. The assets test does not assume a rate of return of 7.8 per cent per annum, as the withdrawal of pension only comes into effect once a person's - assets are above the relevant allowable asset limit. The assets test has a highly generous threshold within which a person's assets do not affect their payment rate. The assets test also allows for many assets, most importantly the home, to be disregarded. A non-homeowner couple, can have assets up to $268,500 and still receive the maximum rate of pension. They can still receive pension with assets up to $464,000. For a homeowner couple the limits are $178,500 and $374,000. The rationale behind the current means test, is that the income and assets tests are designed so that the rate of pension is based on the level of resources available for self-support at the time of assessment. The income and assets test are applied separately and the rate of pension is determined by which ever test returns the lower rate of pension. The means test is also very responsive to people's changing financial needs, as when the level of a person's or couple's resources change, the rate of pension also changes. Under the income test, a deeming rate of 3 per cent per annum applies to the first $30,400 of total financial assets held by a single person, $50,600 for a couple, and a deeming rate of 5 per cent per annum applies to amounts above these levels. The deeming rules, which were announced and legislated for by the previous Government, were introduced to simplify the treatment of financial assets and to make it a much fairer way of assessing people's financial position. Under the old system, different types of financial investments were assessed under different rules, often depending on when the investment was purchased. The old system also caused continual changes in the amount of payment received by customers in many instances. Under the deeming rules, the actual rate of income is ignored in favour of the deemed interest amount. Whilst a deemed rate of return is assumed on financial assets, non financial assets are not deemd. (2) (a) No, the assets test does not discriminate against pensioners owning assets other than financial investments, because financial investments and other assets are treated the same way under the assets test. However, if a person has high levels of assets that produce little or no income, the owners are expected to rearrange their financial affairs before calling on the community for income support through the Social Security system. (b) No, because of the generous thresholds and cutoffs for the pensions assets test. (i) & (ii) Not applicable. Currency and Coinage (Question No. 2573) Mr Martyn Evans asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 December 1997: (1) What role does the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) recognise for optically variable devices in protecting currency from the risks of counterfeiting. (2) Has the RBA invested in research and development of optically variable devices; if so, what are the details. (3) Will the RBA use Excelgram technology on Australian bank notes. (4) To what extent has the RBA promoted the use of Pixelgram or Exelgram technologies on other nations' currencies. (5) Is he able to say whether documents exist indicating that the RBA or CSIRO, or persons acting on behalf of the RBA or CSIRO, sought to prevent or hinder Charter Pacific Corporation Ltd's efforts to raise funds for further development of Pixelgram or Exelgram technologies; if so, can the documents be made public; if not, why not. Mr Costello-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The RBA considers that the use of one or more optically variable devices (eg watermarks) are essential in currency notes, as security devices used to discourage counterfeiters. (2) Following a counterfeiting scare in 1966/67, the RBA instigated a research and development program with CSIRO to develop a more secure currency note. In the early stages of the project, CSIRO identified diffractive optically variable devices (DOVDs) as potentially useful security features The RBA acquired hardware (eg an electron beam lithography machine) and associated software to create DOVD master plates. These were used by staff from CSIRO and the RBA to experiment with designing DOVDs. CSIRO developed a technology called CATPIX for designing DOVDs. The RBA acquired the intellectual property rights to CATPIX technology in 1988. The Commemorative $10 note released in 1988 by the RBA was the first note in the world to incorporate a DOVD and was based on CATPIX technology. (3) The regular use of DOVDs on Australian notes is not currently cost-effective. Changes in counterfeiting risk or cost could alter this assessment in the future. The RBA is keeping under review all the major technologies for designing DOVDs, of which Exelgram is one type. (4) The RBA has not promoted the use of Pixel gram or Exelgram technologies on other nations' currencies. (5) It is not appropriate for me to comment on matters that may be the subject of legal proceedings. Bank Debits Tax Mr Campbell asked the Treasurer, a question without notice, on 29 September 1997: Is it suggested that a tax levied on all bank withdrawals at O.34c would entirely replace income tax. Will the Treasurer have his department make available to members of parliament a synopsis of the relative ments of the debit tax against the Mr Costello--The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: The Commonwealth Government has not undertaken any extensive study of a debits tax. The States already operate financial debits tax systems such as the Bank Account debits tax and the Financial Institutions Duty which raise around $1.9 billion. Debits taxes are complicated and unpopular. I have seen claims that a debit tax of one-third of one per cent on all amounts withdrawn from accounts with banks and other financial institutions would raise enough revenue to replace all other 'federal'taxes. However, this is quite illUSOry. It is highly likely that a debits tax of the type proposed would be avoided on a large scale. This GST. would occur through such means as transactions being netted, moved' offshore or undertaken without resort to the financial system. In addition, the moving offshore of financial transactions would be expected to have a major adverse effect upon our financial services sector, to the benefit of our international competitors. The burden of the tax would fall unfairly on those taxpayers who have little opportunity but to conduct their financial transactions within Australia's geographic boundaries, notably wage and salary earners, the aged and other low income earners.
